name: Ed Sheeran
bio:
[wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Ed Sheeran[/wimpLink] may be the quintessential pop star of the 2010s: a singer/songwriter who seems to acknowledge no boundaries between styles or eras, creating a sound that's idiosyncratic and personal. [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink] borrows from any style that crosses his path -- elements of folk, hip-hop, pop, dance, soul, and rock can be heard in his big hits "The A Team," "Sing," "Thinking Out Loud," and "Shape of You" -- which gives him a broad appeal among different demographics, helping to elevate him to international stardom not long after the release of his 2011 debut, [wimpLink albumId="7967449"]+[/wimpLink].
When [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Ed Sheeran[/wimpLink] released [wimpLink albumId="7967449"]+[/wimpLink], he just had turned 20. He had been playing music since he was a child in Framlingham, Suffolk -- he was born in Halifax, West Yorkshire but his family moved when he was young -- enthralled by the classic rock he heard around the house. [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink] started writing music in his early teens, recording a self-made album called Spinning Man when he was 13 in 2004. In addition to making music at home -- he put out an EP titled The Orange Room in 2005 -- he'd busk on the streets and play whatever stage he could find. When he was 16, he dropped out of school and moved to London so he could make a go of a professional career, landing work as a guitar tech for Nizlopi, gigging whenever he could, and auditioning unsuccessfully for the ITV series Britannia High. The self-released EP [wimpLink albumId="35141366"]You Need Me[/wimpLink] arrived in 2009 -- it followed 2006's eponymous EP and 2007's Want Some? -- but his momentum started to build in 2010 thanks to the EPs [wimpLink albumId="34707583"]Loose Change[/wimpLink] and [wimpLink albumId="35141372"]Songs I Wrote with Amy[/wimpLink] and, especially, performance videos he posted to YouTube. [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink] started to generate considerable buzz -- [wimpLink artistId="7038"]Jamie Foxx[/wimpLink] invited him to appear on his Sirius/XM radio show -- and he landed a deal with Asylum Records in late 2010. After a final independent EP, [wimpLink albumId="15402632"]No. 5 Collaborations[/wimpLink], arrived in January 2011, he signed a contract with [wimpLink artistId="6890"]Elton John[/wimpLink]'s management team.
All of this laid the groundwork for a busy 2011. [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink] entered the studio with Jake Gosling to record his major-label debut. Its first single, "The A Team," arrived in June 2011, entering the charts at number three. August brought "You Need Me, I Don't Need You," setting the stage for the September release of [wimpLink albumId="7967449"]+[/wimpLink]. Assisted by the success of November's single "Lego House," the record became a huge hit in the U.K., a fact underscored by his win of British Breakthrough in the 2012 Brit Awards. [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink]'s success soon spread to Australia, Europe, Canada, and then the United States. He received a boost in the U.S. by opening for [wimpLink artistId="16998"]Snow Patrol[/wimpLink] in 2012, but that paled in comparison to the exposure he received opening for [wimpLink artistId="3557299"]Taylor Swift[/wimpLink] on her [wimpLink albumId="35358097"]Red[/wimpLink] tour in 2013. His endorsement from [wimpLink artistId="3557299"]Swift[/wimpLink], combined with his landing of the closing credits song "I See Fire" for The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug, set [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink] up for an eventful 2014.
Along with reuniting with Jake Gosling, [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink] worked with [wimpLink artistId="6383820"]Rick Rubin[/wimpLink] and [wimpLink artistId="4900204"]Pharrell[/wimpLink] for X, the sophomore set that arrived in June 2014. X debuted at number one on both sides of the Atlantic and generated the huge hits "Thinking Out Loud" and "Sing," success that helped [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink] secure a win for Album of the Year in the 2015 Brit Awards, along with the trophy for Best Male Solo Artist. His success wasn't limited to Britain. X was the second biggest-selling album in the world in 2015, coming in behind [wimpLink artistId="3521920"]Adele[/wimpLink]'s [wimpLink albumId="165814025"]25[/wimpLink], and "Thinking Out Loud" took home the Grammys for Song of the Year and Best Pop Solo Performance in 2016.
[wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Sheeran[/wimpLink] spent the majority of 2016 recuperating and recording his third album with executive producer [wimpLink artistId="3696246"]Benny Blanco[/wimpLink]. Early in 2017, he released two singles, "Castle on the Hill" and "Shape of You," with the latter reaching number one on the charts throughout the world. Their parent album, [wimpLink albumId="70891466"]รท[/wimpLink], appeared in March. [wimpLink albumId="70891466"]รท[/wimpLink] topped the pop charts in over 20 territories, including the U.K. and U.S., and it generated another international hit in "Galway Girl." [wimpLink artistId="3995478"]Ed Sheeran[/wimpLink]'s massive popularity was confirmed in June 2017, when he was awarded an MBE on the occasion of the Queen's Birthday Honours. ~ Stephen Thomas Erlewine
